Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Creating Robust, Adaptable Computational Intelligence by Recreating Key Properties of Animal Brains

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Natural animals display awe-inspiring adaptability and robustness (e.g. three-legged dogs that can still run and catch frisbees). One reason neuroscientists believe animals are so capable is because their brains are structurally organized in that they exhibit neural regularity, modularity, and hierarchy. This project will test whether those neural properties also improve the robustness, adaptability, and overall intelligence of evolved computational agents, specifically robots. Evolutionary algorithms (EAs) evolve, rather than engineer, computational agents to produce qualities seen in nature, such as robustness and adaptability. While EAs often outperform human engineers, the robot bodies and brains they design pale in comparison to those of natural animals. Recent advances by the PI (Professor Clune) and others enable the evolution of neural networks (computational brains) that exhibit regularity, modularity, and hierarchy.

Professor Clune and his students will test whether regularity, modularity, and hierarchy, separately and in combination, improve (1) robustness to noise (2) robustness to damage (3) adaptability to new environments (4) learning, and (5) overall intelligence, measured as the ability to solve challenges of varying complexities. Based on his previous work and preliminary results, Clune anticipates that neural regularity, modularity, and hierarchy could increase all of these desirable behavioral qualities. Such knowledge will accelerate humanity's ability to deploy effective, autonomous robots, which will provide tremendous benefits to society (e.g. search and rescue, putting out fires, and elderly care). The research is woven into a tightly integrated educational plan that generates broader impacts via a robotics club in Laramie, a research-oriented course in evolutionary robotics, public education via videos and the press, and broadening participation in graduate training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER award (which also resulted in a PECASE award for Jeff Clune, the principal investigator for this award) enabled important research into the core themes of the grant. The science for this project went very well and resulted in numerous publications, including many high-impact, highly cited publications in top scientific journals and conferences. Specifically, we investigated how modularity, regularity, and hierarchy in neural networks improve the intelligence and complexity of reinforcement learning agents (e.g. simulated robots). We have also studied how modularity helps solve a grand-challenge in AI research: solving catastrophic forgetting (CF). We have further invented a new form of data-driven plasticity, called diffusion-based neuromodulation, which completely solves CF in simple networks on simple problems, and have investigated its interaction with neural modularity. That work led directly to A Neuromodulated Meta-Learning Algorithm (ANML), which produced state-of-the-art results for continual learning in deep neural networks (aka deep learning). We have also invented a new algorithm called Curiosity Search, and in two papers show that it encourages exploration in RL agents, including when hybridized with deep reinforcement learning. That work led to the publication of a paper in Nature called First Return, Then Explore (introducing the Go-Explore Algorithm), which dramatically advanced the state of the art in deep reinforcement learning for hard-exploration problems. We have additionally published journal papers on hybridizing indirect and direct encodings (allowing a principled combination of neural regularities and exceptions), how evolution learns to generalize to adapt to new environments, the surprising creativity of evolution, how to generate multi-modal robot controllers, and many more subjects. Many other papers were also produced in Jeff Clune’s lab that benefited from the support of this CAREER award, but are not squarely in the original subject area of the grant. Nevertheless, that work has been very high-impact, producing state of the art generative models, revealing that deep neural networks are easily fooled, and showing how deep learning can help other areas of science, namely wildlife biology and conservation biology (e.g. in a paper that was on the cover of PNAS, which led to multiple follow-up papers). A full list of all of these publications can be viewed in Jeff Clune’s CV (http://jeffclune.com/media/Jeff-Clune-CV.pdf) and Google Scholar profile (https://tinyurl.com/JeffClune). Talks summarizing the work in some of the papers can be found at the PI’s website (http://jeffclune.com). Additionally, there was great interest in the general press about work funded by this grant (a list of selected articles is in the PI’s CV). 

 

This grant also helped train the next generation of scientists. Five of my students received a PhD (one is a tenure-track assistant professor, another a non-tenure track assistant professor, two are research scientists at top industrial AI research labs, and one is a data scientist with a major consulting firm). Two are underrepresented minorities (African, Hispanic). Another student received a Master’s degree and works for the University of Wyoming’s IT organization. 

 

Additionally as regards training future scientists, throughout the duration of the grant, we ran the Laramie Robotics Club. It allowed Wyoming children 6th grade and up, including women, minorities, and children of any economic background, to learn (entirely for free) a love for robotics, programming, and STEM. Roughly 20 children attended each week for years, learning to program and getting hands-on experience with robotics. Former members of the club have moved on to college in many cases, including a former LRC member that was accepted to both Harvard and MIT (and chose the former), others that majored in computer science at the University of Wyoming, and another who received a full-ride to MIT and now works on machine learning for the self-driving division of Lyft. 

 

Overall we made great progress on the goals of the grant. I deeply thank the National Science Foundation and the US taxpayers for supporting this research. It has produced many important scientific insights and propelled forward the careers and educational journeys of dozens of individuals.
